items.title: Web Push: Error when sending notification to unsubscribed browser
items.body:
Got Web Push up and running pretty well now, but there seems to be one major flaw in my implementation: If someone unsubscribes from notifications, I get a 410 error and my production app shows an Internal Server Error if I try to send them a notification.

To reproduce:

- Register a browser for web push
- Unregister the service worker on the browser
- Trigger a Web Push notification to a set of devices which includes the browser which has unsubscribed

Result:
```
Internal Server Error: (URI)

WebPushError at (URI)
Push failed: 410 Gone
Response body:push subscription has unsubscribed or expired.
```

What's the best way to avoid this error? I'm planning to put my notification sending in a Celery task to make the site more responsive, which should hide the error from the user, but I'd like to avoid this error. Does it require a fix in django-push-notifications, or is there something I should be doing app-side?

(Perhaps @goinnn encountered this? Sorry for calling on you specifically!)

items.title: Can't get launchOptions when iOS app launched from notification
Support for django3
items.body: Currently, this module uses legacy APIs like `six` and `python2_unicode_compatible`. These have been deprecated for a long time and now have been removed removed from django3.0 onward. `python2_unicode_compatible` has no effect in python3, and can be safely removed. `six.string_types` can be safely replaced by `str`.

items.title: Breaking change in Django 3.0. Need to add six to continue Python 2 support.
items.body:
Django 2.0 dropped official support for python 2, but left in some compatibility APIs for 3rd party apps.

Django 3.0 removed those compatibility APIs (1 month before python 2 end-of-life):
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/releases/3.0/#removed-private-python-2-compatibility-apis

Projects using Django 3.0 and django-push-notifications 1.6.1 fail to run:
```
File ".../push_notifications/models.py", line 3, in <module>
    from django.utils.encoding import python_2_unicode_compatible
ImportError: cannot import name 'python_2_unicode_compatible' from 'django.utils.encoding'
```

This affects:
1) https://github.com/jazzband/django-push-notifications/blob/f0d6b792a3b7ed8ab53fe69091a06f8ff843858e/push_notifications/fields.py#L7
2) https://github.com/jazzband/django-push-notifications/blob/a45f71d58e0d85bb63519f0c12f2526516188177/push_notifications/models.py#L4
3) https://github.com/jazzband/django-push-notifications/blob/a45f71d58e0d85bb63519f0c12f2526516188177/push_notifications/conf/legacy.py#L2
4) https://github.com/jazzband/django-push-notifications/blob/a45f71d58e0d85bb63519f0c12f2526516188177/push_notifications/conf/app.py#L2

It looks like these are only using `string_types` and `python_2_unicode_compatible`, which are both available from the standard "six" package. Is there a preference on adding six as a requirement vs vendoring it?

items.title: Current install is broken, because latest apns2 (0.6.0) is incompatible
items.body:
The project doesn't work with the latest apns2 (0.6.0), which is installed, as per `setup.cfg`: `apns2>=0.3.0`.

APNS2 did some re-ordering of argument types on `payload.Payload` which leads to the following error:

```
>>> dev = APNSDevice.objects.get(pk=35934)
>>> dev.send_message(message="Blah")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/code.py", line 91, in runcode
    exec(code, self.locals)
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/project/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/push_notifications/models.py", line 159, in send_message
    **kwargs
  File "/project/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/push_notifications/apns.py", line 113, in apns_send_message
    certfile=certfile, **kwargs
  File "/project/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/push_notifications/apns.py", line 90, in _apns_send
    data = _apns_prepare(registration_id, alert, **kwargs)
  File "/project/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/push_notifications/apns.py", line 60, in _apns_prepare
    url_args, custom=extra, thread_id=thread_id)
TypeError: __init__() got multiple values for argument 'custom'
```

The resolution in this case is straight-forward. Either:

1) Don't install latest APNS2 (<= 0.5.0)
2) or use only named attributes for all attributes.

Thank you!

items.title: Support for `apns-collapsed-id`
items.body:
It appears that this package does not support the APNS feature `apns-collapse-id`. The apns2 library includes support as a kwarg to `send_notification` or `send_notification_batch` but that kwarg cannot be set via this package's `_apns_send()`.

I don't have a fix available, just documenting that this feature appears to be missing. Thanks.

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'OP_NO_COMPRESSION'
APNS_USE_SANDBOX setting is not respected
items.body:
Documentation states
- `APNS_USE_SANDBOX`: Use 'api.development.push.apple.com', instead of default host 'api.push.apple.com'.

Setting `APNS_USE_SANDBOX` in the `PUSH_NOTIFICATIONS_SETTINGS` has no affect because it is determined by the DJANGO DEBUG environment variable. See `django-push-notifications/push_notifications/settings.py` line 25-28. `APNS_USE_SANDBOX` is overridden by the DJANGO DEBUG environment variable. 

Solution here would be to either update documentation to match the above or source change to respect `APNS_USE_SANDBOX`

items.title: APNS_TOPIC not documented adequately
items.body:
This issue only impacts the unreleased master branch.

If APNS_TOPIC is not present in settings, sending an APNS notification fails. The setting is mentioned in the example configuration but is not defined under the APNS settings section. It would be appropriate to default APNS_TOPIC to "" in settings given the following [developer documentation](https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/NetworkingInternet/Conceptual/RemoteNotificationsPG/CommunicatingwithAPNs.html).

> The topic of the remote notification, which is typically the bundle ID for your app. The certificate you create in your developer account must include the capability for this topic.
If your certificate includes multiple topics, you must specify a value for this header.
If you omit this request header and your APNs certificate does not specify multiple topics, the APNs server uses the certificate’s Subject as the default topic.
If you are using a provider token instead of a certificate, you must specify a value for this request header. The topic you provide should be provisioned for the your team named in your developer account.

```

    def to_bytestring(element):
        """
        Converts a single string to a bytestring, encoding via UTF-8 if needed.
        """
        if isinstance(element, unicode):
            return element.encode('utf-8')
```

items.title: Application Support 1.5 Proposal
items.body:
This is an intermediate step before implementing full in database support for multiple applications. 

* Move drf and tastypie integrations into push_notifications.contrib. Add deprecated warnings at their current location for backwards compatibility.
* Add support for configuration adapters.
    * Add a LegacySettingsAdapter that supports the existing format. (this will be default)
    * Add a AppIDSettingsAdapter that address applications by application_id for all platforms. (this will be default)
* Add support for application_id based on the current PR but skip any "other" features at this time.

This proposal suggests an alternate settings format as well as formally supporting additional contributed features via a push_notifications.contrib module. The drf and tastypie integrations would be moved here (with links maintained in their old locations for backwards compatibility). 

Additionally, the registry module that provides mobile clients to register tokens and other backend services to send push notifications through an API would be under push_notifications.contrib. (more to come on registry in another proposal).

```
PUSH_NOTIFICATIONS_SETTINGS = {
    # defines where to load application configuration from,
    # default will be the old file format from settings.py (LegacySettingsAdapter).
    "CONFIG_ADAPTER": "push_notifications.adapters.AppIDSettingsAdapter"

    # new array of all applications in the push_notifications
    "APPLICATIONS": [
        {
            # required - indicates what fields are needed to get api key or details: FCM, GCM, IOS, WNS
            "PLATFORM": "FCM",

            # required, how to address messages to this client from code
            "APPLICATION_ID": "my_fcm_app" 

            # optional, will be "default", allows for addressing devices across platform boundaries.
            # For instance, I have an android and ios version of my application
            # and I'd like to notify all users of a special announcement.
            "APPLICATION_GROUP": "my_application",

            # optional. if set, integrates with contrib.registry to allow mobile
            # applications to add keys (in situations where user authentication is not desired)
            "APPLICATION_SECRET": "d0910e22bd008b8ef603f5432d1e7020568ca0e9"

            # fcm setting
            "API_KEY": "[your api key]",
        },
        {
            "PLATFORM": "IOS",  # required - indicates what fields are needed to get api key or details: FCM, GCM, IOS, WNS

            # required, how to address messages to this client from code
            "APPLICATION_ID": "my_ios_app" 

            # optional, will be "default", allows for addressing devices across platform boundaries.
            # For instance, I have an android and ios version of my application
            # and I'd like to notify all users of a special announcement.
            "APPLICATION_GROUP": "my_application",

            # optional. if set, integrates with contrib.registry to allow mobile
            # applications to add keys (in situations where user authentication is not desired)
            "APPLICATION_SECRET": "d0910e22bd008b8ef603f5432d1e7020568ca0e9"

            # ios setting
            "APNS_CERTIFICATE": "/path/to/your/certificate.pem",
        },
        {
            "PLATFORM": "WNS",  # required - indicates what fields are needed to get api key or details: FCM, GCM, IOS, WNS

            # required, how to address messages to this client from code
            "APPLICATION_ID": "my_wns_app" 

            # optional, will be "default", allows for addressing devices across platform boundaries.
            # For instance, I have an android and ios version of my application
            # and I'd like to notify all users of a special announcement.
            "APPLICATION_GROUP": "my_application",

            # optional. if set, integrates with contrib.registry to allow mobile
            # applications to add keys (in situations where user authentication is not desired)
            "APPLICATION_SECRET": "d0910e22bd008b8ef603f5432d1e7020568ca0e9"

            # wns settings
            "WNS_PACKAGE_SECURITY_ID": "[your package security id, e.g: 'ms-app://e-3-4-6234...']",
            "WNS_SECRET_KEY": "[your app secret key, e.g.: 'KDiejnLKDUWodsjmewuSZkk']",
        }
    ]
}
```

items.title: Wrong implementation of FCM
items.body:
Hello,

I think your implementation of FCM (#302) is wrong.

2 reasons:

First:
In docs we have requests with Content-Type: application/json
Your implementation - application/x-www-form-urlencoded;charset=UTF-8
Docs - https://firebase.google.com/docs/cloud-messaging/send-message

Second:
A body is wrong - FCM expects JSON with keys: to, data, notification. But you send dict with key registration_id

Docs - https://firebase.google.com/docs/cloud-messaging/concept-options#notifications_and_data_messages

As result, I wrote trash-implementation in commit https://github.com/WarmongeR1/django-push-notifications/commit/7fdad2a2079db1049c7c807b287d62672bf5e611
I didn't fix tests, I only demonstrate work version of code

And current interface `send_message` is unsuitable for FCM.
Because if we send Push-notification with FCM we should write

`python
device.send_message(None, extra={'notification': {'body': 'lfdlfds'}})
`


Sorry for my bad english.

items.title: Having a "WebPush" device --does it make sense?
items.body:
I started to use this project before fully understanding what is a WebPush and what is a Push. Given that I wanted to perform WebPush for Android Chrome browsers, I was focused on the GCM stuff and forgot to teach myself about WebPush and its requirements --mainly the required encryption mechanisms.

The current GCM device here is somewhat compatible with Chrome WebPush browsers, but because they lack encryption it is not possible to send information from the server to the client (at least, that is what I understood from [google](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/03/web-push-encryption) and [mozilla](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Push_API/Using_the_Push_API), sorry for my ignorance).

In the end I rolled my own library (my requirements were very modest) using the [`pywebpush`](https://github.com/web-push-libs/pywebpush/) which provides the encryption requirements for the WebPush I wanted. However, I was thinking that maybe a WebPushDevice would be a "good feature" to `django-push-notifications`.

Does it make sense? Or it would clutter the library and it is not the same philosophy as the current devices?

items.title: GCMDevice fails on Postgres (Django 1.9+)
items.body:
When storing the 64-bit device ID for GCM devices, it has to be converted to a signed integer on Postgres backends.

However, the name of the Postgres backend was changed in Django 1.9: now `django.db.backends.postgresql` is the preferred way while `django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2` remains as fallback:

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/ref/settings/#engine

Thus, the list of `signed_integer_engines` in fields.py has to be extended so that both names are supported:

https://github.com/jleclanche/django-push-notifications/blob/master/push_notifications/fields.py#L18

All in all, the current implementation of `HexIntegerField` seems rather delicate and susceptible to bugs. For instance, only the global `connection` object is used in `_using_signed_storage` as opposed to the connection the field is actually used with (`connection` argument). Then, fuzzy matching is performed in `db_type` but exact matching is required for `signed_integer_engines`. However, since this is out of scope for this issue, discussion should probably move to another ticket.

items.title: The field device_id in Android must be a char field
items.body:
It's not a good idea to identify the device with a hardware value, what you want to identify is the installation. The best way to do that are an `uuid` or `InstanceId.getId()` (or the new `FirebaseInstanceId.getId()`). I'm not the only one that think so: [Best Practices for Unique Identifiers](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids.html).

The problem is that the model enforce us to store a hexadecimal value in `device_id` and this values aren't a hexadecimal values, they are strings.

A string filed can handle a hexadecimal value if you really want to store the `ANDROID_ID` or the `TelephonyManager.getDeviceId()` so this probably isn't a BC.

items.title: Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) support?
items.body:
Google's [docs](https://developers.google.com/cloud-messaging/) recommend building new apps with FCM rather than GCM:

> Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) is the new version of GCM. It inherits the reliable and scalable GCM infrastructure, plus new features! See the FAQ to learn more. If you are integrating messaging in a new app, start with FCM. GCM users are strongly recommended to upgrade to FCM, in order to benefit from new FCM features today and in the future.

I'm interested to hear others' opinions on this:
- Should I follow their advice? There doesn't seem to be a deprecation timeline for GCM.
- If FCM is the way to go, should I integrate by adapting `push_notifications` with something like an `FCMDevice`, or use a different library?

items.title: APNSServerError: (8, 0) with Celery
items.body:
